articles.headline: ‘Lied to the World’ or Acted in ‘Good Faith’: Sam Bankman-Fried’s Trial Opens
articles.snippet: Prosecutors said the FTX founder had lied to customers. Defense lawyers said he had just been trying to prevent his cryptocurrency exchange from melting down.
articles.abstract: Prosecutors said the FTX founder had lied to customers. Defense lawyers said he had just been trying to prevent his cryptocurrency exchange from melting down.
articles.lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors on Wednesday opened the criminal trial of Sam Bankman-Fried, the founder of the failed cryptocurrency exchange FTX, with a simple message: He deliberately “lied to the world,” leading to one of the biggest financial frauds of a generation.
articles.byline: By David Yaffe-Bellany, Matthew Goldstein and J. Edward Moreno

articles.headline: From a Capitol Hill Basement, Bannon Stokes the Republican Party Meltdown
articles.snippet: The former Trump adviser has helped create the spectacle of G.O.P. dysfunction, using it to build his own following and those of the right-wing House rebels who took down Kevin McCarthy.
articles.abstract: The former Trump adviser has helped create the spectacle of G.O.P. dysfunction, using it to build his own following and those of the right-wing House rebels who took down Kevin McCarthy.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Wednesday morning, two Republicans who hours earlier had toppled Kevin McCarthy as speaker of the House made a well-worn trek to a 19th-century brick townhouse a few blocks away from the Capitol and entered the cluttered sanctuary of Stephen K. Bannon’s recording studio.

articles.headline: New U.A.W. Chief Has a Nonnegotiable Demand: Eat the Rich
articles.snippet: Shawn Fain’s disdain for the “billionaire class” informs his showdown with Detroit’s automakers. Now he must prove that his hard-core tactics pay off.
articles.abstract: Shawn Fain’s disdain for the “billionaire class” informs his showdown with Detroit’s automakers. Now he must prove that his hard-core tactics pay off.
articles.lead_paragraph: For as long as anyone can remember, the Indiana city of Kokomo has been a conservative stronghold. Ronald Reagan crushed Walter Mondale in Kokomo. Bill Clinton lost twice. So did Barack Obama. The current mayor, a Republican, is running unopposed for re-election. It’s a town known for something it would prefer to forget: a Ku Klux Klan rally in 1923 that was the largest ever.

articles.headline: A Start-Up’s Alternative to Uber: Employing Its Own Drivers
articles.snippet: Alto is trying to fill a more expensive niche, especially as politicians and labor groups argue that the contractor model exploits drivers.
articles.abstract: Alto is trying to fill a more expensive niche, especially as politicians and labor groups argue that the contractor model exploits drivers.
articles.lead_paragraph: The white S.U.V. pulled away from the curb at Dallas Fort Worth International Airport, bound for downtown Dallas. There was an issue.

articles.headline: A Giacometti for a Cezanne: Jeffrey Epstein’s Role in a Pricey Art Deal
articles.snippet: Mr. Epstein helped the billionaire Leon Black defer capital gains taxes from the swap. A Senate committee is scrutinizing some of Mr. Black’s art deals as it looks into tax avoidance schemes.
articles.abstract: Mr. Epstein helped the billionaire Leon Black defer capital gains taxes from the swap. A Senate committee is scrutinizing some of Mr. Black’s art deals as it looks into tax avoidance schemes.
articles.lead_paragraph: In late 2016, when the private equity mogul Leon Black was trying to sell one expensive piece of art to buy another without incurring a hefty tax bill, he turned to the one man he knew who could help pull it off: his friend Jeffrey Epstein.

articles.headline: Women Could Fill Truck Driver Jobs. Companies Won’t Let Them.
articles.snippet: Three women filed a discrimination complaint against a trucking company over its same-sex training policy, which they say prevented them from being hired.
articles.abstract: Three women filed a discrimination complaint against a trucking company over its same-sex training policy, which they say prevented them from being hired.
articles.lead_paragraph: The trucking industry has complained for years that there is a dire shortage of workers willing to drive big rigs. But some women say many trucking companies have made it effectively impossible for them to get those jobs.

articles.headline: U.S. Will Build Stretch of Border Wall and Begin Deportations to Venezuela
articles.snippet: The decisions underscore the challenges facing the Biden administration as humanitarian crises around the world drive more migrants to the U.S. border.
articles.abstract: The decisions underscore the challenges facing the Biden administration as humanitarian crises around the world drive more migrants to the U.S. border.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Biden administration on Thursday said it would expand former President Donald Trump’s wall on the Mexican border and begin deporting thousands of Venezuelans in an effort to cut down on the migrant surge that shows no signs of abating.
articles.byline: By Miriam Jordan, Eileen Sullivan and Zolan Kanno-Youngs

articles.headline: The Remaking of The Wall Street Journal
articles.snippet: Emma Tucker, the top editor, is moving away from some of the organization’s traditions.
articles.abstract: Emma Tucker, the top editor, is moving away from some of the organization’s traditions.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last month, Emma Tucker, the new editor in chief of The Wall Street Journal, gathered the newsroom to share a blunt message: The media industry had morphed “beyond recognition” and The Journal needed to adapt, or be left behind.
